bestBHT.bht: The sin of Sodom and Gomorrah, specifically their departure from the natural order of sexuality, serves as a warning against immorality. The punishment they faced, the eternal fire that consumed their cities, is a type of the future punishment that awaits the ungodly. This severity of suffering shows the intensity of God's judgement. The destruction of these cities serves as a monument of God's vengeance and serves as an example for all to fear the consequences of such wickedness.

Henry Alford: The sin of Sodom was afterwards common in the most enlightened nations of antiquity.
But in all probability Sodom and Gomorrah must be numbered among those whose sin went further even than this.
Undergoing the punishment, as even now be seen, of eternal fire: of that fire which shall never be quenched.
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: departing from the course of nature, and going after that which is unnatural.
The lasting marks of the fire that consumed the cities irreparably, is a type of the eternal fire to which the inhabitants have been consigned.
Albert Barnes: The cities of Sodom and Gomorrah furnishes a warning against all such conduct, and a demonstration that punishment shall come upon the ungodly.
The word 'strange' or 'other,' refers to that which is contrary to nature.
The phrase 'eternal fire' is one that is often used to denote future punishment - as expressing the severity and intensity of the suffering.
Marvin Vincent: The force of ejk is out and out; giving themselves up utterly.
Turning away from purity, and going after strange flesh.
Those cities are most truly an example of eternal fire.
John Calvin: And Jude also mentions in what follows, that the fire through which the five cities perished was a type of the eternal fire.
Then God at that time exhibited a remarkable example, in order to keep men in fear till the end of the world.
We ought to observe, that he devotes them to eternal fire; for we hence learn, that the dreadful spectacle which Moses describes, was only an image of a much heavier punishment.
Archibald T. Robertson: Horrible licentiousness, not simply with women not their wives or in other nations, but even unnatural uses.
John Gill: Their sin was alike; which sin is a work of the flesh, contrary to the law of God, is against the body, and attended with many evils.
Men; and designs that detestable and unnatural sin, which, from these people, is called sodomy to this day.

Their punishment follows, are set forth for an example; being destroyed by fire from heaven, and their cities turned into a sulphurous lake, which continues to this day, as a monument of God's vengeance.
John Wesley: The cities which gave themselves over to fornication — The word here means, unnatural lusts.
Are set forth as an example, suffering the vengeance of eternal fire.
That is, the vengeance which they suffered is an example or a type of eternal fire.

bhtAttempts.bht: The sin of Sodom and Gomorrah, which included departing from the natural order of sexuality, serves as a warning against all forms of immorality. The punishment they faced, the eternal fire that consumed their cities and left lasting marks, is a type of the eternal fire that awaits the ungodly. This serves as a demonstration of the severity and intensity of future punishment. Jude mentions how their sin is like that of the fallen angels, exhibiting a detestable and unnatural act that goes against God's law. The destruction of these cities by fire from heaven serves as a lasting monument of God's vengeance and a reminder to all to fear the consequences of such wickedness.

The sin of Sodom, an example of going after strange flesh, was a departure from the course of nature. The punishment they experienced, the eternal fire that consumed their cities, serves as a type of the eternal fire of God's judgement. This serves as a warning against all forms of immorality, as the severity and intensity of their suffering demonstrate the consequences of ungodliness. Their destruction remains a lasting monument of God's vengeance and a reminder of the punishment that awaits the wicked.

The sin of Sodom and Gomorrah, specifically their departure from the natural order of sexuality, serves as a warning against immorality. The punishment they faced, the eternal fire that consumed their cities, is a type of the future punishment that awaits the ungodly. This severity of suffering shows the intensity of God's judgement. The destruction of these cities serves as a monument of God's vengeance and serves as an example for all to fear the consequences of such wickedness.

The sin of Sodom and Gomorrah, characterized by its departure from the natural order of sexuality, serves as a strong warning against immorality. Their punishment, the eternal fire that consumed their cities, illustrates the severity and intensity of God's judgement. This serves as a lasting reminder of the consequences that await the ungodly. The destruction of these cities stands as a solemn monument of God's vengeance and should instill fear in the hearts of all who consider the consequences of such wickedness.

The sin of Sodom and Gomorrah, departing from the natural order and engaging in unnatural acts, serves as a warning against immorality. Their punishment, the eternal fire that consumed their cities, is a type of the future punishment for the ungodly. This severity of suffering reflects the intensity of God's judgement. The destruction of these cities remains a lasting monument of God's vengeance and serves as an example to fear the consequences of such wickedness.
